qas.question: What did PCB designers used to employ on a mylar sheet?
In the old PCB design method, what was used to connect component pin pads?
What were traces originally made out of?
Designers would rub on a dry transfer of what to make the process of laying out components simpler?
What kind of metal coated the blank boards used to make PCBs?

plausible_answers.text: by creating a photomask on a clear mylar sheet

qas.question: Initially PCBs were designed mechanically how?

plausible_answers.text: traces were routed to connect the pads

qas.question: Pin pads were laid out on the nylon and then what?
Self-adhesive mylar was used to make what?
Pre-printed reproducing grids on the mylar assisted in what?
Printed copper-clad boards were used to make what?

context: Initially PCBs were designed manually <b5_0>by creating a <a0_0>photomask<a0_0/> on a clear mylar sheet<b5_0/>, usually at two or four times the true size. Starting from the schematic diagram the component pin pads were laid out on the mylar and then <a1_0><b6_0>traces<a1_0/> were routed to connect the pads<b6_0/>. Rub-on dry transfers of <a3_0>common component footprints<a3_0/> increased efficiency. <b7_0>Traces<b7_0/> were made with <a2_0>self-adhesive tape<a2_0/>. Pre-printed non-reproducing grids on the mylar assisted in <b8_0>layout<b8_0/>. To fabricate the board, <b9_0>the finished photomask<b9_0/> was photolithographically reproduced onto a photoresist coating on the blank <a4_0>copper<a4_0/>-clad boards.
